questions.question: In a population of 1,000 diploid individuals at a locus with two alleles (A and a), you observe 360 AA, 480 Aa, and 160 aa individuals. What are the allele frequencies, and is this population in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium?
options: p(A) = 0.6, q(a) = 0.4; the population IS in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium because observed genotype frequencies match expected frequencies
p(A) = 0.6, q(a) = 0.4; the population is NOT in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium because there is an excess of heterozygotes
p(A) = 0.36, q(a) = 0.64; the population is in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium
p(A) = 0.48, q(a) = 0.52; the population cannot be tested for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium
questions.explanation: First, calculate allele frequencies: p(A) = (2×360 + 480)/(2×1000) = 1200/2000 = 0.6; q(a) = (2×160 + 480)/(2×1000) = 800/2000 = 0.4. Under Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, expected frequencies are: AA = p² = 0.36, Aa = 2pq = 0.48, aa = q² = 0.16. Expected counts: AA = 360, Aa = 480, aa = 160. These match the observed counts exactly, so the population IS in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Option B is incorrect because 480 Aa individuals out of 1000 equals exactly the expected 2pq = 0.48, not an excess. Option C is incorrect because p represents the allele frequency, not the genotype frequency; 0.36 is the frequency of the AA genotype. Option D incorrectly calculates allele frequencies using heterozygote frequency directly.

questions.question: A population of beetles has two alleles at a color locus: B (brown, dominant) and b (green, recessive). In a sample of 10,000 beetles, 100 are green (bb). Assuming Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, approximately how many beetles are expected to be heterozygous carriers (Bb)?
options: Approximately 100
Approximately 900
Approximately 1,800
Approximately 9,000
questions.explanation: From the data: frequency of bb (q²) = 100/10,000 = 0.01, so q = 0.1 and p = 0.9. The expected frequency of heterozygotes (Bb) = 2pq = 2(0.9)(0.1) = 0.18. In 10,000 beetles: 0.18 × 10,000 = 1,800 heterozygous carriers. This demonstrates a key insight from population genetics: recessive alleles are hidden in heterozygous carriers at far higher frequencies than they appear in homozygous recessive individuals. Here, while only 1% show the green phenotype, 18% carry at least one copy of the b allele. Option A is incorrect because 100 represents only the homozygous recessive individuals. Option B would be the expected number if 2pq = 0.09, which would require different allele frequencies. Option D is incorrect because 9,000 would represent p² × 10,000 = the number of BB homozygotes.

questions.question:
A geneticist tracks allele frequency changes at a neutral locus across 10 replicate populations of Drosophila, each founded with 20 individuals and an initial frequency of allele A₁ = 0.5:

| Generation | Pop 1 | Pop 2 | Pop 3 | Pop 4 | Pop 5 | Pop 6 | Pop 7 | Pop 8 | Pop 9 | Pop 10 |
|-----------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|--------|
| 0 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 0.50 |
| 20 | 0.65 | 0.30 | 0.80 | 0.45 | 0.00 | 0.55 | 1.00 | 0.20 | 0.70 | 0.40 |
| 50 | 0.90 | 0.00 | 1.00 | 0.15 | 0.00 | 0.80 | 1.00 | 0.00 | 1.00 | 0.10 |

This pattern is BEST explained by:
options: Natural selection consistently favoring allele A₁ in all populations
Mutation pressure converting A₂ to A₁ at a high rate
Genetic drift in small populations causing random fluctuations in allele frequencies, with some populations reaching fixation (1.0) or loss (0.0) of the allele
Gene flow between populations homogenizing allele frequencies
questions.explanation: This pattern is a textbook demonstration of genetic drift in small populations. All 10 populations started at the same allele frequency (0.5) for a neutral locus, yet by generation 50, the frequencies have diverged dramatically — with some populations fixing A₁ (frequency = 1.0), others losing it completely (frequency = 0.0), and others at intermediate but variable frequencies. The random, unpredictable direction of change across replicate populations is the hallmark of genetic drift. With only 20 founders (effective population size N = 20), drift is powerful and rapid. Option A is incorrect because natural selection would push all populations in the same direction, not produce random divergence in both directions. Option B is incorrect because mutation rates are far too low to change allele frequencies this dramatically in 50 generations. Option D is incorrect because gene flow would homogenize frequencies across populations, producing convergence rather than divergence.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an assumption of the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium model?
options: No natural selection acting on the locus in question
Random mating with respect to the locus
The population must consist of exactly 500 individuals
No migration (gene flow) into or out of the population
questions.explanation: Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium requires five assumptions: (1) no mutation, (2) random mating, (3) no natural selection, (4) infinitely large population size (no genetic drift), and (5) no gene flow (migration). The model does NOT require a specific population size of 500 — rather, it requires a population large enough that random sampling effects (genetic drift) are negligible, theoretically infinite. Option A is a genuine assumption — selection alters genotype frequencies. Option B is a genuine assumption — non-random mating (assortative mating, inbreeding) changes genotype but not allele frequencies. Option D is a genuine assumption — migration introduces or removes alleles, altering frequencies.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about genetic drift:
S1: Genetic drift has a greater effect on allele frequencies in small populations than in large populations.
S2: Genetic drift can lead to the fixation of deleterious alleles in small populations.
S3: Genetic drift always increases the frequency of beneficial alleles in a population.
S4: The founder effect and bottleneck effect are both special cases of genetic drift that reduce genetic variation.
options: TTFT
TTTT
TFFT
TFTF
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE because in small populations, random sampling of gametes produces larger deviations from expected allele frequencies, causing more rapid and unpredictable frequency changes. In large populations, random fluctuations average out, minimizing drift's effect. S2 is TRUE because drift is random with respect to fitness — a deleterious allele can increase in frequency and even reach fixation by chance in a small population, especially when the selective disadvantage (s) is much less than 1/(2N). S3 is FALSE because drift is random and directionless; it can decrease beneficial allele frequencies just as easily as increase them. In small populations, drift can even overpower weak positive selection, causing loss of beneficial alleles. S4 is TRUE because both the founder effect (a few individuals colonize a new area) and the bottleneck effect (population crashes and recovers) involve small population sizes that magnify drift, typically reducing genetic variation through random loss of alleles.

questions.question: In a population with two alleles at a locus (A₁ and A₂), the fitness values are: W(A₁A₁) = 1.0, W(A₁A₂) = 1.0, W(A₂A₂) = 0.7. What is the selection coefficient against the A₂A₂ genotype, and what type of selection is occurring?
options: s = 0.3; directional selection favoring the A₁ allele with A₁ dominant over A₂
s = 0.7; stabilizing selection maintaining both alleles
s = 0.3; overdominance (heterozygote advantage) maintaining a balanced polymorphism
s = 1.0; disruptive selection eliminating heterozygotes
questions.explanation: The selection coefficient s = 1 - W(A₂A₂) = 1 - 0.7 = 0.3, representing a 30% fitness reduction for A₂A₂ homozygotes relative to the fittest genotype. Since W(A₁A₁) = W(A₁A₂) = 1.0, the A₁ allele is dominant for fitness — heterozygotes have the same fitness as A₁A₁ homozygotes. This is directional selection against the recessive A₂ allele. Under this selection regime, A₂ frequency will decrease over time, but the rate of decrease slows as A₂ becomes rarer (because most A₂ alleles are hidden in heterozygotes). Option B is incorrect because s is calculated as the fitness deviation from the maximum, not the fitness itself. Option C is incorrect because overdominance requires W(A₁A₂) > W(A₁A₁) and W(A₁A₂) > W(A₂A₂), which is not the case here. Option D is incorrect because disruptive selection would favor both homozygotes over heterozygotes.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether a particular allele (A₁) is increasing in frequency due to positive natural selection or genetic drift in a wild mouse population. Which experimental approach would BEST distinguish between these two mechanisms?
options: Measuring the population size once at a single time point

Comparing the rate of frequency change of the A₁ allele to neutral genetic markers across multiple independent populations — if A₁ increases consistently across populations while neutral markers drift randomly, positive selection is supported
Sequencing the A₁ allele in a single individual to look for mutations
Observing the color of mice carrying A₁ to determine if it provides camouflage
questions.explanation: Comparing the allele frequency trajectory at the candidate locus to neutral markers across replicate populations is a powerful method to distinguish selection from drift. Under drift alone, all loci (including the candidate) should show random, uncorrelated frequency changes across populations. Under positive selection, the candidate allele should increase consistently across multiple independent populations while neutral markers continue to drift randomly. This approach — comparing patterns at selected vs. neutral loci — underlies many statistical tests for selection (e.g., FST outlier tests, selective sweep detection). Option A is incorrect because a single census cannot distinguish drift from selection. Option C is incorrect because sequencing one individual reveals sequence composition but not population-level frequency changes or their causes. Option D might suggest a functional mechanism but cannot definitively distinguish selection from drift at the population level.

questions.question: Sickle cell disease is caused by homozygosity for the HbS allele at the beta-globin locus. In malaria-endemic regions of sub-Saharan Africa, heterozygotes (HbA/HbS) have higher fitness than either homozygote. If the fitness values are W(HbA/HbA) = 0.89, W(HbA/HbS) = 1.0, and W(HbS/HbS) = 0.20, what is the expected equilibrium frequency of the HbS allele?
options: q̂ = 0.50 because heterozygote advantage always maintains equal allele frequencies
q̂ = 0 because the HbS allele is always deleterious
q̂ = 1.0 because heterozygotes are the fittest genotype
questions.explanation: Under heterozygote advantage (overdominance), the equilibrium frequency of the deleterious allele is q̂ = s₁/(s₁ + s₂), where s₁ is the selection coefficient against one homozygote and s₂ against the other. Here, s₁ = 1 - 0.89 = 0.11 (selection against HbA/HbA from malaria susceptibility) and s₂ = 1 - 0.20 = 0.80 (selection against HbS/HbS from sickle cell disease). Therefore q̂ = 0.11/(0.11 + 0.80) = 0.11/0.91 ≈ 0.121, predicting ~12.1% frequency of the HbS allele at equilibrium. This matches observed frequencies in malaria-endemic regions. Option B is incorrect because equal frequencies occur only when s₁ = s₂, which is not the case here (malaria susceptibility and sickle cell disease impose very different fitness costs). Option C is incorrect because while HbS is deleterious in homozygotes, it provides a heterozygote advantage that maintains it in the population. Option D is incorrect because heterozygote advantage maintains both alleles, not fixation of either.

questions.question: A population geneticist observes that a population of wildflowers shows a deficit of heterozygotes at all surveyed loci compared to Hardy-Weinberg expectations, but allele frequencies are not changing over generations. The most likely explanation is:
options: Strong directional selection against heterozygotes at all loci
A high rate of mutation generating new alleles
Inbreeding (non-random mating among relatives), which increases homozygosity without changing allele frequencies
Gene flow from a neighboring population with different allele frequencies
questions.explanation: Inbreeding is the most likely explanation for a genome-wide deficit of heterozygotes without allele frequency changes. Inbreeding (mating among relatives) increases homozygosity at all loci simultaneously because related individuals share alleles by descent. Critically, inbreeding changes genotype frequencies (increasing homozygotes, decreasing heterozygotes) without changing allele frequencies — a key distinction from selection or drift. Self-pollinating wildflowers are particularly prone to inbreeding. Option A is unlikely because selection against heterozygotes (underdominance) at all loci simultaneously would be biologically implausible, and it would change allele frequencies. Option B is incorrect because mutation introduces new alleles (potentially increasing heterozygosity) but would not systematically decrease heterozygosity. Option D is incorrect because gene flow introduces new alleles that could increase or decrease heterozygosity depending on the source population, but would also change allele frequencies.

questions.question: The neutral theory of molecular evolution, proposed by Motoo Kimura, states that:
options: Natural selection is the only force driving molecular evolution
All mutations are beneficial and fixed by positive selection
Most molecular evolutionary changes are caused by random fixation of selectively neutral or nearly neutral mutations through genetic drift, not by positive natural selection
Genetic drift has no effect on allele frequencies at the molecular level
questions.explanation: Kimura's neutral theory (1968) proposes that the vast majority of molecular evolutionary changes (substitutions at the DNA and protein level) are selectively neutral or nearly neutral and are fixed by genetic drift rather than positive selection. This does not deny the role of natural selection in adaptive evolution but argues that at the molecular level, most observed variation and substitution is non-adaptive. Key evidence includes the approximately clock-like rate of molecular substitution, the correlation between substitution rate and functional constraint (more constrained proteins evolve slower), and the enormous amount of genetic variation in natural populations. Option A is incorrect because the neutral theory specifically argues against selection being the primary driver of molecular evolution. Option B is incorrect because most mutations under the neutral theory are selectively neutral, not beneficial. Option D is incorrect because the neutral theory places genetic drift as the central mechanism of molecular evolution.

questions.question:
Researchers measured beak depth in a population of medium ground finches (Geospiza fortis) before and after a severe drought that eliminated most small, soft seeds, leaving only large, hard seeds:

| Measurement | Before Drought | After Drought (survivors) |
|-------------|---------------|-------------------------|
| Mean beak depth (mm) | 9.42 | 10.14 |
| Variance in beak depth | 0.93 | 0.68 |
| Heritability (h²) of beak depth | 0.79 | — |

Using the breeder's equation (R = h² × S), what is the predicted evolutionary response if the selection differential S = 10.14 - 9.42 = 0.72 mm?
options: R = 0.72 mm; the next generation will have mean beak depth of 10.14 mm
R = 0.79 × 0.72 = 0.569 mm; the next generation is predicted to have a mean beak depth of approximately 9.42 + 0.569 = 9.99 mm
R = 0 because beak depth cannot evolve
R = 0.93 × 0.72 = 0.670 mm; the next generation will have mean beak depth of 10.09 mm
questions.explanation: The breeder's equation R = h² × S predicts the evolutionary response (R) to selection, where h² is heritability and S is the selection differential (difference between the mean of selected parents and the population mean before selection). R = 0.79 × 0.72 = 0.569 mm. The predicted mean beak depth in the next generation = original mean + R = 9.42 + 0.569 ≈ 9.99 mm. The response is less than the selection differential because only the heritable component of phenotypic variation (79%) contributes to the evolutionary response; the remaining 21% is environmental variance that is not transmitted to offspring. This calculation closely matches the actual data from the Grants' classic study on Daphne Major. Option A incorrectly assumes R = S (which would require h² = 1.0, meaning all variation is genetic). Option C is incorrect because beak depth clearly can evolve given sufficient heritability and selection. Option D incorrectly uses variance instead of heritability in the equation.

questions.question:
A population of lizards shows the following fitness values for body size genotypes at a single locus:

W(SS) = 0.75 (small), W(SM) = 1.0 (medium), W(MM) = 0.85 (large)

Which type of selection is operating, and what is the predicted long-term outcome?
options: Directional selection; the S allele will be fixed
Balancing selection (overdominance); both alleles will be maintained at a stable equilibrium because heterozygotes have the highest fitness
Disruptive selection; the population will split into two size morphs
Stabilizing selection; both homozygous genotypes will be equally common
questions.explanation: When the heterozygote (SM) has higher fitness than either homozygote (SS or MM), this is overdominance (heterozygote advantage), a form of balancing selection. Both alleles will be maintained at a stable equilibrium because selection works against both homozygotes. The equilibrium frequency of the S allele can be calculated: q̂(M) = s₁/(s₁ + s₂) = 0.25/(0.25 + 0.15) = 0.625, so p̂(S) = 0.375. At this equilibrium, any perturbation (increase or decrease in either allele frequency) is counteracted by selection, maintaining the polymorphism indefinitely. Option A is incorrect because the S allele is selected against in SS homozygotes, so it cannot be fixed. Option C is incorrect because disruptive selection requires both homozygotes to have higher fitness than heterozygotes — the opposite of this scenario. Option D is incorrect because stabilizing selection on a continuous trait is not the same as overdominance at a single locus.

questions.question: The effective population size (Ne) of a population is often much smaller than the census population size (N). Which factor does NOT reduce Ne relative to N?
options: Fluctuating population size across generations
Unequal sex ratio among breeding individuals
High variance in reproductive success among individuals
Random mating with equal reproductive success among all individuals
questions.explanation: Random mating with equal reproductive success is actually the idealized condition under which Ne = N. All the other factors reduce effective population size below census size. Option A (fluctuating population size) reduces Ne because Ne is the harmonic mean of population sizes across generations, which is heavily influenced by the smallest population sizes (bottlenecks). Option B (unequal sex ratio) reduces Ne because fewer breeding individuals of the rarer sex limits the number of independent genetic lineages; Ne ≈ 4NfNm/(Nf + Nm). Option C (high variance in reproductive success) reduces Ne because when some individuals contribute disproportionately to the next generation, the genetic effective population is smaller than the census count. Many real populations have Ne/N ratios of 0.1-0.5.

questions.question: A researcher suspects that frequency-dependent selection is maintaining a color polymorphism in a prey species (rare morphs have a survival advantage because predators form search images for common morphs). Which experimental design would BEST test this hypothesis?
options: Measuring the proportion of each color morph in the population at a single time point

Manipulating the frequency of color morphs in experimental enclosures with predators and measuring morph-specific survival rates at different starting frequencies — if rare morphs survive better, negative frequency-dependent selection is confirmed
Sequencing the genome of each color morph to identify the genetic basis of coloration
Measuring body size differences between color morphs to determine which is more fit
questions.explanation: Frequency-dependent selection predicts that the fitness of a morph depends on its frequency in the population. The most direct test is to experimentally manipulate morph frequencies and measure fitness (survival) as a function of frequency. If survival of a morph increases when it is rare and decreases when it is common (negative frequency-dependent selection), this confirms the hypothesis. This classic experimental design has been used successfully with prey polymorphisms, demonstrating that predators disproportionately target common morphs due to search image formation. Option A describes the pattern but does not test the mechanism. Option C identifies genetic basis but not the selective mechanism maintaining variation. Option D measures fitness components unrelated to frequency dependence.

questions.question: In a Hardy-Weinberg population with three alleles at a locus (A₁, A₂, A₃) with frequencies p = 0.5, q = 0.3, and r = 0.2, what is the expected frequency of heterozygotes (all heterozygous genotypes combined)?
questions.explanation: With three alleles, the total heterozygote frequency = 1 - (sum of homozygote frequencies) = 1 - (p² + q² + r²). Homozygote frequencies: p² = 0.25, q² = 0.09, r² = 0.04. Sum = 0.38. Total heterozygote frequency = 1 - 0.38 = 0.62. Alternatively, this can be calculated as 2pq + 2pr + 2qr = 2(0.5)(0.3) + 2(0.5)(0.2) + 2(0.3)(0.2) = 0.30 + 0.20 + 0.12 = 0.62. This demonstrates that multi-allelic loci maintain higher heterozygosity than two-allele loci. Option A represents only the A₁A₂ heterozygote frequency (2pq = 0.30). Option C represents the total homozygote frequency (p² + q² + r² = 0.38). Option D is incorrect arithmetic.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about mutation as an evolutionary force:
S1: Mutation is the ultimate source of all new genetic variation in populations.
S2: Mutation rates are typically high enough (>0.1 per locus per generation) to drive significant allele frequency changes in a single generation.
S3: Mutation-selection balance occurs when the rate of introduction of deleterious alleles by mutation equals their rate of removal by selection.
S4: Mutation alone, without selection, drift, or gene flow, can cause evolution by changing allele frequencies over many generations.
options: TFTT
TTTT
TFTF
TTFT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE because all genetic variation — point mutations, insertions, deletions, duplications, chromosomal rearrangements — ultimately originates from mutation events. Without mutation, there would be no raw material for evolution. S2 is FALSE because mutation rates are typically very low (~10⁻⁴ to 10⁻⁹ per locus per generation depending on organism and locus), far too low to cause significant allele frequency changes in a single generation. Mutation is a weak evolutionary force per generation but powerful over long timescales as the ultimate source of variation. S3 is TRUE because at mutation-selection balance, the frequency of a deleterious allele reaches an equilibrium (q̂ ≈ μ/s for dominant alleles, q̂ ≈ √(μ/s) for recessive alleles) where mutational input balances selective elimination. S4 is TRUE because mutation pressure, even without other forces, can gradually shift allele frequencies. If mutation A→a occurs at rate μ with no back-mutation, the frequency of allele a will eventually reach 1.0, though this takes an extremely long time at typical mutation rates.

questions.question: A population of snails has a shell color locus with two alleles. After a severe hurricane, only 15 individuals survive from a population of 10,000. The surviving 15 snails happen to have very different allele frequencies from the original population. This scenario describes:
options: Natural selection favoring hurricane-resistant snail morphs
A population bottleneck resulting in genetic drift — the random survival of a non-representative genetic sample that may differ substantially from the original population
Gene flow from a neighboring population
Increased mutation rate triggered by the environmental stress of the hurricane
questions.explanation: This is a classic population bottleneck — a dramatic reduction in population size that causes allele frequencies to shift due to random sampling (genetic drift). The 15 survivors represent a small, random sample of the original genetic diversity, and their allele frequencies may differ substantially from the pre-bottleneck population by chance alone. The bottleneck also reduces genetic variation because rare alleles are likely to be lost. Importantly, the hurricane did not selectively kill snails based on their shell color alleles — the survival was random with respect to the genetic locus in question. Option A is incorrect because the question states the survivors 'happen to have' different frequencies, implying random survival rather than selective survival based on shell color. Option C is incorrect because no migration from an external population is involved. Option D is incorrect because environmental stress does not increase the per-locus mutation rate in a directed manner.

questions.question: Sexual selection can maintain traits that reduce survival (such as the peacock's elaborate tail). Which mathematical condition must be met for a sexually selected trait to be maintained despite its survival cost?
options: The trait must have zero heritability so it does not respond to natural selection
The mutation rate for the trait must be zero

The mating advantage conferred by the trait must exceed the survival disadvantage, such that the net fitness (combining both mating success and survival) of individuals with the trait is higher than those without it
The trait must be expressed only in females, not males
questions.explanation: For a sexually selected trait to persist despite a survival cost, it must provide sufficient mating advantage to more than compensate for reduced survival. Total fitness is the product of survival probability and mating success: if a male with an elaborate tail has 80% the survival of a plain male but 200% the mating success, his net fitness (0.80 × 2.00 = 1.60) exceeds the plain male's (1.00 × 1.00 = 1.00). The trait is maintained as long as the mating advantage outweighs the survival cost. Option A is incorrect because the trait must be heritable for sexual selection to drive evolutionary change. Option B is irrelevant because mutation rates have minimal effect on whether sexual selection maintains a trait. Option D is incorrect because many sexually selected traits (bright plumage, elaborate displays, large antlers) are expressed in males, not females.

questions.question:
A population of plants was surveyed for flower color, controlled by a single locus with two alleles (R = red, dominant; r = white, recessive). Over five years, the following phenotype frequencies were recorded:

| Year | Red Flowers | White Flowers | Total |
|------|------------|---------------|-------|
| 1 | 750 | 250 | 1000 |
| 2 | 760 | 240 | 1000 |
| 3 | 775 | 225 | 1000 |
| 4 | 790 | 210 | 1000 |
| 5 | 810 | 190 | 1000 |

Calculating the frequency of the r allele over time: Year 1 q = √0.25 = 0.50; Year 5 q = √0.19 = 0.436. What is the most likely cause of this allele frequency change?
options: Genetic drift, because the change is gradual and random
Mutation from R to r at an increasing rate each year

Directional selection against the white (rr) phenotype, as the consistent directional decrease in the r allele frequency across all years indicates a non-random force systematically reducing the recessive allele
The population is in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium with no evolutionary change
questions.explanation: The consistent, unidirectional decrease in white flower frequency (and the r allele) over all five years strongly suggests directional selection against the rr phenotype. If this were genetic drift, we would expect random fluctuations in both directions, not a consistent decrease. The pattern is most consistent with selection acting against white-flowered individuals (perhaps pollinators prefer red flowers, or white flowers are more visible to herbivores). From Year 1 to Year 5, q decreased from 0.50 to 0.436 — a change too large and directional for drift in a population of 1,000. Option A is unlikely because drift produces random fluctuations, not consistent directional change, especially in a population of 1,000 individuals. Option B is incorrect because mutation from R to r would increase, not decrease, the frequency of r. Option D is incorrect because allele frequencies are clearly changing.

questions.question: The concept of 'migration-selection balance' in population genetics refers to a situation where:
options: Migration and selection both favor the same allele, causing rapid fixation
Gene flow introduces alleles from neighboring populations at a rate that balances their removal by local selection, maintaining allele frequencies at an intermediate equilibrium
Migration prevents all forms of selection from occurring
Selection causes organisms to migrate to more favorable habitats
questions.explanation: Migration-selection balance occurs when gene flow from external populations continuously introduces alleles that are locally deleterious, while local natural selection removes them. The balance between influx (migration) and removal (selection) maintains the deleterious allele at an intermediate equilibrium frequency (q̂ ≈ m/(m+s) for a haploid model, where m is the migration rate and s is the selection coefficient). This is important for understanding why locally maladaptive alleles persist in populations receiving gene flow from populations adapted to different environments. Option A describes reinforcing forces that would cause rapid fixation, not balance. Option C is incorrect because migration does not prevent selection; both operate simultaneously. Option D confuses ecological migration (behavioral habitat choice) with genetic gene flow between populations.

questions.question: In a population of 2,000 individuals, the inbreeding coefficient F = 0.15. If the allele frequency of allele A is p = 0.6, what is the expected frequency of AA homozygotes under inbreeding?
questions.explanation: Under inbreeding, the genotype frequencies deviate from Hardy-Weinberg expectations. The frequency of AA homozygotes = p² + Fpq, where F is the inbreeding coefficient. This is because inbreeding increases homozygosity by converting a fraction F of heterozygotes into homozygotes proportional to allele frequencies. Calculating: p² + Fpq = (0.6)² + 0.15(0.6)(0.4) = 0.36 + 0.036 = 0.396. Similarly, heterozygote frequency = 2pq(1-F) = 0.48(0.85) = 0.408 (reduced from 0.48), and aa frequency = q² + Fpq = 0.16 + 0.036 = 0.196. Total: 0.396 + 0.408 + 0.196 = 1.000. Option A gives the Hardy-Weinberg expectation without accounting for inbreeding. Option C gives the heterozygote frequency under Hardy-Weinberg, not the homozygote frequency under inbreeding. Option D incorrectly adjusts p² downward rather than upward.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about gene flow:
S1: Gene flow tends to homogenize allele frequencies between populations, reducing genetic differentiation.
S2: Even very low rates of gene flow (1 migrant per generation in a population of N individuals) can prevent genetic drift from causing substantial differentiation between populations.
S3: Gene flow always increases the fitness of recipient populations by introducing beneficial alleles.
S4: Gene flow can counteract local adaptation by introducing alleles that are locally maladapted but favored in the source population.
options: TTFT
TTTT
TFTF
TTFF
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE because gene flow moves alleles between populations, tending to equalize allele frequencies. The greater the gene flow, the more similar populations become genetically (FST ≈ 1/(4Nm + 1), where Nm = number of migrants). S2 is TRUE because even 1 migrant per generation (Nm = 1) results in FST ≈ 0.2, preventing substantial differentiation. This is Wright's 'one migrant per generation' rule — a surprisingly small amount of gene flow effectively counteracts drift-driven divergence. S3 is FALSE because gene flow can decrease fitness by introducing locally maladapted alleles (migration load). For example, gene flow from lowland populations to high-altitude populations can introduce alleles poorly suited to high-altitude conditions. Gene flow is not inherently beneficial. S4 is TRUE because gene flow from a source population adapted to different conditions introduces alleles that may be disadvantageous in the local environment, counteracting local adaptation. This creates migration-selection balance and can prevent populations from reaching their local fitness optimum.

questions.question: A researcher observes that in a population of guppies, the mean tail spot number has remained stable at 7 spots for 200 generations despite heritable variation in spot number. This is most consistent with:
options: Disruptive selection favoring extreme spot numbers
Directional selection for increasing spot number
Stabilizing selection maintaining intermediate spot numbers near the phenotypic optimum
No selection of any kind acting on tail spots
questions.explanation: The maintenance of a stable mean phenotype over many generations despite heritable variation is the hallmark of stabilizing selection. Under stabilizing selection, individuals with extreme phenotypes (very few or very many spots) have lower fitness than individuals near the population mean, which is maintained at or near the fitness optimum. This selection purges extreme variants each generation, maintaining the mean while reducing phenotypic variance. Option A is incorrect because disruptive selection would favor extreme phenotypes and tend to shift the population away from intermediate values. Option B is incorrect because directional selection would cause the mean to shift over generations, not remain stable. Option D is incorrect because without any selection, the mean might still remain stable, but we would not expect the consistent maintenance of a specific optimum value with heritable variation unless some force maintains it. The presence of stable heritability and a constant mean over 200 generations strongly implicates stabilizing selection.

questions.question: According to the nearly neutral theory (Ohta, 1973), which mutations are most susceptible to the effects of genetic drift?
options: Strongly beneficial mutations with large positive selection coefficients
Strongly deleterious mutations with large negative selection coefficients
Mutations with selection coefficients near zero (|s| ≈ 1/2Ne), where the effective population size is small enough that drift overwhelms weak selection
Mutations that are lethal in all environments
questions.explanation: Ohta's nearly neutral theory extends Kimura's neutral theory by recognizing that mutations with very small selection coefficients (|s| ≈ 1/2Ne or smaller) behave as effectively neutral — their fate is determined primarily by genetic drift rather than selection. When the absolute value of the selection coefficient is less than approximately 1/(2Ne), the stochastic effects of drift overwhelm the deterministic effects of selection. This means that in small populations (low Ne), a wider range of slightly deleterious mutations behave as effectively neutral, potentially reducing population fitness. Option A is incorrect because strongly beneficial mutations (s >> 1/2Ne) are efficiently fixed by positive selection regardless of drift. Option B is incorrect because strongly deleterious mutations are efficiently purged by purifying selection. Option D is incorrect because lethal mutations (s = 1) are always removed by selection regardless of population size.

questions.question:
A researcher measures FST (a measure of genetic differentiation) among populations of three species:

| Species | Number of Populations | Mean FST | Dispersal Ability |
|---------|----------------------|----------|------------------|
| Migratory bird | 8 | 0.02 | High (continental migration) |
| Forest snail | 12 | 0.45 | Very low (sedentary) |
| River fish | 6 | 0.18 | Moderate (within river systems) |

What is the most likely explanation for the variation in FST among species?
options: The migratory bird has the highest genetic differentiation because it travels the farthest

Species with higher dispersal ability have higher gene flow between populations, reducing genetic differentiation (lower FST), while sedentary species accumulate greater differentiation through drift and local selection
FST values are unrelated to dispersal ability and reflect only mutation rates
All three species have equivalent levels of gene flow, and the FST differences are measurement artifacts
questions.explanation: The data show a clear inverse relationship between dispersal ability and FST: the migratory bird (high dispersal) has the lowest FST (0.02), the sedentary snail (low dispersal) has the highest FST (0.45), and the river fish (moderate dispersal) is intermediate (0.18). This pattern is predicted by population genetics theory: FST ≈ 1/(4Nm + 1), where Nm is the number of migrants per generation. High dispersal increases gene flow (Nm), reducing differentiation. Low dispersal restricts gene flow, allowing drift and local selection to increase differentiation. Option A is incorrect because high dispersal reduces FST. Option C is incorrect because FST is primarily determined by the balance between gene flow and drift, with mutation playing a secondary role at typical timescales. Option D is incorrect because the consistent correlation with biology rules out measurement artifacts.

questions.question: A lethal recessive allele (a) with fitness W(aa) = 0 is maintained at an equilibrium frequency of q = 0.01 in a large population. Assuming mutation-selection balance, what is the estimated mutation rate (μ) from A to a?
questions.explanation: For a lethal recessive allele (s = 1), the mutation-selection balance equation is q̂ = √(μ/s). With s = 1 (lethal) and q = 0.01: 0.01 = √(μ/1), so μ = q² = (0.01)² = 0.0001 = 10⁻⁴. This represents the forward mutation rate from A to a needed to maintain the lethal recessive allele at 1% frequency. The equilibrium exists because each generation, selection removes aa homozygotes (q² proportion of individuals), while mutation creates new a alleles at rate μ. At equilibrium, these rates balance. Option A incorrectly equates mutation rate with allele frequency. Option C arrives at the same numerical answer but uses an incorrect formula pathway. Option D uses the formula for mutation-selection balance with a dominant lethal allele (q = μ/s), not a recessive one.

questions.question: Which of the following scenarios would most likely lead to disruptive selection in a population?
options: A predator that preferentially attacks the most common phenotype in a prey population
An environment where intermediate-sized seeds are the most abundant food source
An environment where food resources are bimodally distributed (abundant small and large seeds but few intermediate-sized seeds), favoring individuals with either small or large beaks
An environment with stable, predictable conditions that favor the population mean
questions.explanation: Disruptive selection occurs when extreme phenotypes have higher fitness than intermediate phenotypes, potentially splitting the population into distinct morphs. A bimodal resource distribution — abundant small and large seeds with few intermediate seeds — would favor birds with either small beaks (efficient at small seeds) or large beaks (efficient at large seeds), while selecting against intermediate beaks that are suboptimal for both seed sizes. This creates the conditions for disruptive selection and potentially sympatric speciation. Option A describes negative frequency-dependent selection, not disruptive selection — it favors rare phenotypes regardless of whether they are extreme. Option B describes conditions favoring stabilizing selection on beak size. Option D describes stabilizing selection where the mean phenotype is optimal.

questions.question: A conservation geneticist wants to determine whether a recently bottlenecked population of endangered tigers has lost significant genetic diversity. Which combination of genetic analyses would be MOST informative?
options: Measuring only the body weight of individuals in the population
Sequencing a single mitochondrial gene in five individuals
Genotyping multiple microsatellite loci and comparing observed heterozygosity, allelic richness, and effective population size to historical museum samples collected before the bottleneck
Counting the number of stripes on each tiger to assess phenotypic variation
questions.explanation: Comparing current genetic diversity to pre-bottleneck historical samples provides the most informative assessment of diversity loss. Microsatellite loci (highly polymorphic, codominant markers) allow measurement of heterozygosity, allelic richness, and effective population size estimation. Comparing these metrics between current populations and museum specimens (pre-bottleneck) directly quantifies the genetic diversity lost during the bottleneck. Allelic richness is particularly sensitive to bottlenecks because rare alleles are preferentially lost. Option A is incorrect because body weight is influenced by nutrition and environment, providing little information about genetic diversity. Option B provides limited information because mtDNA is a single locus with uniparental inheritance and limited resolution for detecting bottleneck effects. Option D measures phenotypic variation that is heavily influenced by environmental factors and poorly reflects underlying genetic diversity.

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes the relationship between the strength of natural selection and the rate of adaptive evolution?
options: Stronger selection always produces faster adaptive evolution regardless of the amount of genetic variation

Adaptive evolution requires both heritable genetic variation and natural selection; the rate of adaptive evolution depends on the product of selection intensity and additive genetic variance (as described by Fisher's fundamental theorem)
The rate of adaptive evolution depends only on mutation rate and is independent of selection
Adaptive evolution occurs only in small populations where drift can fix beneficial alleles
questions.explanation: Fisher's fundamental theorem of natural selection states that the rate of increase in mean fitness of a population equals the additive genetic variance in fitness. This means adaptive evolution requires both selection (to provide directionality) and additive genetic variance (to provide the raw material for response). Without genetic variation, even strong selection cannot produce evolutionary change; without selection, genetic variation does not produce adaptive change. The breeder's equation (R = h²S) captures this relationship for individual traits. Option A is incorrect because without genetic variation, selection cannot produce evolutionary change — this is a common misconception. Option C is incorrect because mutation provides the ultimate source of variation but the rate of adaptive evolution also depends on how selection acts on that variation. Option D is incorrect because adaptive evolution is more efficient in large populations where beneficial alleles are more likely to be fixed by selection rather than lost to drift.

questions.question: A population of rabbits exhibits assortative mating for coat color (dark rabbits preferentially mate with dark rabbits, light with light). Compared to a randomly mating population with the same allele frequencies, the assortatively mating population will have:
options: Higher heterozygosity and no change in allele frequencies
Lower heterozygosity and changed allele frequencies
Lower heterozygosity at the coat color locus (and linked loci) but unchanged allele frequencies
No change in genotype frequencies because mate choice does not affect evolution
questions.explanation: Positive assortative mating (like mating with like) increases homozygosity and decreases heterozygosity at the loci affecting the mated trait and linked loci, but does NOT change allele frequencies. This is because assortative mating redistributes existing alleles into more homozygous combinations without adding or removing alleles from the population. The effect is similar to inbreeding for the specific loci involved but differs because it is trait-specific rather than genome-wide. Option A is incorrect because assortative mating decreases heterozygosity, not increases it. Option B is incorrect because while heterozygosity decreases, allele frequencies remain unchanged under assortative mating. Option D is incorrect because mate choice clearly affects genotype frequencies even though it does not change allele frequencies.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the sources of genetic variation in populations:
S1: Sexual reproduction through recombination and independent assortment generates new combinations of existing alleles, increasing genotypic diversity without creating new alleles.
S2: Gene duplication followed by divergence of the duplicate copy can create new genes with novel functions.
S3: Transposable elements can insert into or near genes, sometimes altering gene expression or function and providing a source of genetic variation.
S4: Genetic variation is always beneficial to individual organisms.
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE because sexual reproduction combines existing alleles through meiotic recombination (crossing over) and independent assortment of chromosomes, generating enormous genotypic diversity from existing genetic variation. In a species with 10,000 variable loci each with 2 alleles, the number of possible genotypes exceeds the number of atoms in the universe. S2 is TRUE because gene duplication provides a spare copy that is freed from purifying selection and can accumulate mutations leading to neofunctionalization (new function), subfunctionalization (partitioning of ancestral function), or pseudogenization (loss of function). S3 is TRUE because transposable elements can alter gene expression by inserting into regulatory regions, create new exons (exonization), or generate chromosomal rearrangements, contributing to genetic variation. S4 is FALSE because most new mutations (and thus most genetic variation) are neutral or deleterious to individual fitness. Variation is beneficial to populations (providing raw material for adaptation) but often harmful to individuals carrying deleterious alleles.

questions.question: Clinal variation — a gradual change in allele frequency or phenotype along a geographic gradient — is most commonly maintained by:
options: Identical selection pressures across the entire range producing uniform phenotypes
The interaction between spatially varying selection (different optima at different locations) and gene flow between adjacent populations along the gradient
Complete reproductive isolation between populations at each point along the cline
Random genetic drift operating identically at all locations
questions.explanation: Clinal variation results from a balance between spatially varying selection (which pushes local populations toward different phenotypic optima) and gene flow (which tends to homogenize adjacent populations). The gradient in selection pressures creates a gradient in optimal phenotypes, while gene flow between nearby populations smooths this gradient into a continuous cline rather than discrete steps. Classic examples include the latitudinal cline in Drosophila body size (Bergmann's rule) and altitudinal clines in plant morphology. Option A is incorrect because identical selection everywhere would produce uniformity, not a cline. Option C is incorrect because complete isolation would produce discrete differences between populations, not a smooth gradient. Option D is incorrect because drift produces random variation, not the systematic geographic pattern characteristic of clines.

questions.question: A geneticist studying the MHC (Major Histocompatibility Complex) locus in humans finds that heterozygosity at MHC loci is significantly higher than expected under neutrality, and that MHC alleles show much greater sequence divergence than neutral loci with similar divergence times. This pattern is consistent with:
options: Purifying selection removing all variation at MHC loci
Genetic drift increasing heterozygosity by random fixation

Balancing selection maintaining high allelic diversity at MHC loci, likely through heterozygote advantage (individuals heterozygous at MHC can present a wider range of pathogen peptides) and/or negative frequency-dependent selection (rare alleles confer resistance to pathogens that have evolved to evade common MHC alleles)
A recent selective sweep reducing variation at MHC loci
questions.explanation: The exceptionally high polymorphism at MHC loci — with hundreds of alleles maintained for millions of years (trans-species polymorphism, where the same allelic lineages are shared between humans and chimpanzees) — is maintained by balancing selection through two mechanisms. Heterozygote advantage: individuals heterozygous at MHC loci can present peptides from a wider range of pathogens, providing broader immune protection. Negative frequency-dependent selection: rare MHC alleles confer an advantage because pathogens evolve to evade recognition by common MHC alleles, giving rare alleles a selective advantage. Option A is incorrect because purifying selection would reduce variation, not maintain extraordinary levels of it. Option B is incorrect because drift cannot consistently maintain excess heterozygosity — it tends to reduce variation over time. Option D is incorrect because selective sweeps reduce variation (hitchhiking effect), the opposite of the observed pattern.

questions.question:
A researcher tracked the frequency of a pesticide resistance allele (R) in two populations of mosquitoes over 10 generations:

| Generation | Population A (N=10,000, sprayed) | Population B (N=10,000, unsprayed) |
|-----------|-------------------------------|----------------------------------|
| 0 | 0.01 | 0.01 |
| 2 | 0.05 | 0.012 |
| 4 | 0.18 | 0.009 |
| 6 | 0.42 | 0.011 |
| 8 | 0.71 | 0.010 |
| 10 | 0.89 | 0.008 |

What evolutionary forces best explain the allele frequency dynamics in each population?
options: Genetic drift in both populations

Positive selection driving R to high frequency in Population A (sprayed), while the R allele remains at mutation-selection balance in Population B (unsprayed) due to a fitness cost of resistance in the absence of pesticide
Gene flow from Population A to Population B increasing R frequency in both
Mutation pressure increasing R frequency in Population A only
questions.explanation: In Population A (sprayed), the R allele increases rapidly from 0.01 to 0.89 in 10 generations — a rate far too fast for drift or mutation alone, consistent with strong positive selection (pesticide exposure favoring resistant mosquitoes). In Population B (unsprayed), the R allele remains low (~0.01) and even slightly decreases, suggesting a fitness cost of resistance in the absence of pesticide — the R allele is maintained at low frequency by mutation-selection balance (mutation introduces R, selection against the fitness cost removes it). This is a classic example of context-dependent fitness: the R allele is beneficial in the presence of pesticide but slightly deleterious in its absence. Option A is incorrect because the directional, rapid increase in Population A cannot be explained by drift. Option C is incorrect because the populations show opposite trajectories, not convergence. Option D is incorrect because mutation rates are too low to explain the rapid frequency increase observed.

questions.question: Which statement about the relationship between population size and the efficiency of natural selection is correct?
options: Natural selection is more efficient in small populations because there are fewer competing genotypes
Population size has no effect on the efficiency of natural selection
Natural selection is less efficient in small populations because genetic drift can overpower weak selection, allowing slightly deleterious alleles to fix and slightly beneficial alleles to be lost
Natural selection only operates in populations with exactly 1,000 individuals
questions.explanation: In small populations, the random sampling effects of genetic drift are powerful enough to overwhelm weak selection. Specifically, when the absolute value of the selection coefficient |s| < 1/(2Ne), the allele behaves as effectively neutral — its fate is determined by drift rather than selection. This means small populations accumulate slightly deleterious mutations that would be purged by selection in large populations, and fail to fix slightly beneficial mutations that would be favored in large populations. This 'drift load' reduces the mean fitness of small populations. Option A is incorrect because small populations are less efficient at selection due to stronger drift. Option B is incorrect because population size profoundly affects selection efficiency. Option D is incorrect because selection operates at all population sizes but with varying efficiency.

questions.question: In a population of frogs, males with deeper calls attract more females. A researcher measures call frequency and finds that males with deeper calls also grow more slowly and reach smaller adult body sizes. Despite this trade-off, deep-voiced males have higher overall fitness. This situation illustrates:
options: That trade-offs between traits prevent any adaptation from occurring
That natural selection can only improve one trait at a time and must sacrifice all others

That sexual selection for deeper calls can drive evolution of lower call frequency despite antagonistic natural selection on correlated traits (growth rate and body size), because the net fitness benefit from mating success outweighs the survival cost
That the frogs are not evolving because the population is at Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium
questions.explanation: This scenario illustrates the complexity of multivariate selection and trade-offs. Deep-voiced males face a trade-off: their preferred call frequency comes at the cost of slower growth and smaller body size. However, the mating advantage (sexual selection component) more than compensates for the survival/growth cost (natural selection component), resulting in higher net fitness. Evolution in multi-trait space follows the path that maximizes overall fitness, even when this involves accepting suboptimal values for some traits. This is why organisms are not 'perfectly' adapted for any single function. Option A is incorrect because trade-offs constrain but do not prevent adaptation. Option B is incorrect because selection acts on total fitness, considering all traits simultaneously. Option D is incorrect because the population is clearly evolving through sexual selection.

questions.question: A selective sweep occurs when a new beneficial mutation rapidly increases in frequency, carrying linked neutral variants to high frequency through genetic hitchhiking. Which molecular signature would you expect to find in the genomic region surrounding a recent selective sweep?
options: Increased genetic diversity and heterozygosity in the flanking regions
No change in any molecular features compared to the rest of the genome
An excess of common alleles relative to rare alleles (positive Tajima's D)
Reduced genetic diversity, an excess of rare variants (negative Tajima's D), and extended linkage disequilibrium in the region surrounding the selected locus
questions.explanation: A recent selective sweep leaves a characteristic molecular signature: (1) Reduced genetic diversity — the rapid fixation of the beneficial allele and linked variants eliminates variation in the flanking region. (2) An excess of rare variants (negative Tajima's D) — after the sweep, new mutations begin accumulating, and these new mutations are rare; the absence of intermediate-frequency variants (swept away) creates a negative Tajima's D. (3) Extended linkage disequilibrium (LD) — the rapid fixation event did not allow enough time for recombination to break up associations between the selected allele and linked variants, creating long haplotype blocks. These signatures are used in genomic scans for selection (e.g., iHS, XP-EHH tests). Option A is incorrect because sweeps reduce diversity. Option B is incorrect because sweeps leave clear molecular signatures. Option C (positive Tajima's D) is associated with balancing selection, not sweeps.

questions.question: To determine whether observed phenotypic differences between two populations of the same fish species are due to genetic adaptation (evolved differences) or phenotypic plasticity (environmental effects), the MOST definitive experimental approach would be:
options: Measuring the phenotypes of fish from both populations in their natural habitats
Sequencing the genomes of fish from both populations to identify genetic differences

A common garden experiment: rearing fish from both populations under identical environmental conditions from birth and comparing their phenotypes — if differences persist, they have a genetic basis; if they disappear, they were environmentally induced
Comparing the diets of fish from both populations to determine environmental influences
questions.explanation: A common garden (or transplant) experiment is the gold standard for distinguishing genetic from environmental causes of phenotypic differences. By rearing organisms from both populations under identical controlled conditions, environmental variation is eliminated. If phenotypic differences persist in the common environment, they must have a genetic basis (evolved adaptation). If they disappear, the original differences were due to phenotypic plasticity. Reciprocal transplant experiments (rearing each population in both environments) provide additional power by also quantifying genotype-by-environment interactions. Option A cannot distinguish genetic from environmental causes because populations differ in both. Option B identifies genetic differences but cannot determine which differences are functionally responsible for phenotypic variation. Option D characterizes one environmental variable but cannot establish causation or distinguish from genetic effects.

questions.question: The probability that a new beneficial mutation with selection coefficient s will eventually fix in a diploid population of effective size Ne is approximately:
options: 1/(2Ne) regardless of the selection coefficient
s/(1-e^(-4Nes)), which for large populations with strong selection simplifies to approximately 2s
1.0 (100%) because all beneficial mutations are guaranteed to fix
0 because beneficial mutations are always lost to drift
questions.explanation: The fixation probability of a new beneficial mutation in a diploid population is given by Kimura's formula: P(fix) ≈ (1 - e^(-2s))/(1 - e^(-4Nes)). For large populations where 4Nes >> 1, this simplifies to approximately 2s. This means even a strongly beneficial mutation (say s = 0.05, a 5% fitness advantage) only has about a 10% chance of fixing — most beneficial mutations are lost by drift while still rare. This is because a new mutation exists as a single copy, and its frequency can fluctuate to zero before selection becomes effective. Option A gives the fixation probability of a neutral mutation, not a beneficial one. Option C is incorrect because even beneficial mutations have substantial probability of being lost by drift while rare. Option D is incorrect because beneficial mutations have higher fixation probability than neutral mutations, though fixation is not guaranteed.

questions.question: The Wahlund effect describes a pattern where pooling data from two or more genetically differentiated subpopulations produces an apparent deficit of heterozygotes compared to Hardy-Weinberg expectations, even though each subpopulation may be in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium individually. This occurs because:
options: Subpopulations always have identical allele frequencies

Pooling populations with different allele frequencies mathematically increases the expected proportion of homozygotes (since the average of squares exceeds the square of the average), creating an apparent heterozygote deficit
Heterozygotes migrate between populations more than homozygotes
Mutation rates differ between subpopulations, generating excess heterozygotes
questions.explanation: The Wahlund effect arises from a mathematical property: when populations with different allele frequencies are pooled, the average frequency of homozygotes (E[p²]) exceeds the square of the average allele frequency (p̄²). This is because variance in p across subpopulations inflates homozygosity: E[p²] = p̄² + Var(p). Since the expected heterozygosity of the pooled sample uses p̄ while actual homozygosity reflects E[p²], the pooled sample shows an apparent heterozygote deficit equal to the variance in allele frequencies across subpopulations (which is the definition of FST). Option A is incorrect because the Wahlund effect specifically requires different allele frequencies between subpopulations. Option C is incorrect because differential migration of genotypes is unrelated to the mathematical basis of the Wahlund effect. Option D is incorrect because mutation rate differences do not explain the heterozygote deficit from population pooling.

questions.question: A researcher discovers that a population of birds has an unusually high frequency (0.30) of a recessive allele that causes reduced wing length. In the laboratory, homozygous recessive birds have 40% lower survival than wild-type birds. Which explanation BEST accounts for the high frequency of this apparently deleterious allele?
options: The population must be very large, preventing drift from reducing the allele frequency
The allele is maintained at high frequency because it is beneficial in all environments
The mutation rate from wild-type to reduced-wing allele must be extremely high
Heterozygous carriers may have a fitness advantage over both homozygotes (overdominance), creating a stable balanced polymorphism that maintains the deleterious allele at high frequency
questions.explanation: An allele frequency of 0.30 for a recessive allele causing 40% reduced survival in homozygotes is far too high to be explained by mutation-selection balance alone (which would predict q ≈ √(μ/s) ≈ √(10⁻⁵/0.4) ≈ 0.005). The most likely explanation is heterozygote advantage (overdominance), where heterozygous carriers have higher fitness than either homozygote, maintaining the deleterious allele at a stable intermediate frequency (analogous to sickle cell and malaria). Option A is incorrect because large population size would make selection more efficient at removing deleterious alleles, not less. Option B is incorrect because the allele is explicitly deleterious in homozygotes. Option C is incorrect because mutation rates of the magnitude required to maintain q = 0.30 (μ = sq² = 0.4 × 0.09 = 0.036) are biologically unrealistic for a single locus.

questions.question: Two adjacent populations of mice exchange migrants at a rate m = 0.05 per generation. Population 1 has allele frequency p₁ = 0.8 and Population 2 has p₂ = 0.2. After one generation of migration, what will be the new allele frequency in Population 1 (assuming only migration, no other forces)?
options: p₁' = 0.80 (unchanged)
p₁' = 0.50 (average of the two populations)
p₁' = 0.20 (replaced by Population 2's frequency)
questions.explanation: The one-island migration model predicts that after one generation, the allele frequency in the recipient population becomes: p' = p(1-m) + p_source(m), where m is the fraction of individuals that are migrants. For Population 1: p₁' = 0.8(1-0.05) + 0.2(0.05) = 0.8(0.95) + 0.2(0.05) = 0.76 + 0.01 = 0.77. The frequency shifts toward the source population's frequency by a fraction proportional to the migration rate and the frequency difference. The change Δp = -m(p₁ - p₂) = -0.05(0.6) = -0.03. Option A is incorrect because migration with frequency differences always changes the recipient population's frequency. Option B would only be reached after many generations of symmetric migration. Option D would require complete replacement (m = 1).

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about types of natural selection:
S1: Directional selection shifts the mean phenotype toward one extreme, reducing variation on that side of the distribution.
S2: Stabilizing selection reduces phenotypic variance without changing the mean, by selecting against extreme phenotypes on both tails.
S3: Disruptive selection reduces phenotypic variance by favoring intermediate phenotypes.
S4: Frequency-dependent selection can maintain genetic polymorphism when rare phenotypes have a fitness advantage.
options: TTFT
TTTT
TFTF
TTFF
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE because directional selection favors one phenotypic extreme, shifting the mean toward that extreme and truncating variation on the favored side. Over time, the population mean changes in the direction of selection. S2 is TRUE because stabilizing selection acts against both phenotypic extremes, favoring individuals near the mean. This does not change the mean but reduces the variance (spread) of the phenotypic distribution. S3 is FALSE because disruptive selection favors both extremes over intermediates, INCREASING phenotypic variance (not reducing it) and potentially creating a bimodal distribution. S4 is TRUE because negative frequency-dependent selection (where rare types are favored) prevents any single type from dominating, maintaining multiple alleles/phenotypes in the population. This is a mechanism of balancing selection and is observed in host-parasite coevolution, predator-prey search image dynamics, and self-incompatibility systems.

questions.question: The expected heterozygosity at a neutral locus in a population at mutation-drift equilibrium is given by H = 4Neμ/(4Neμ + 1), where Ne is the effective population size and μ is the mutation rate. What does this equation predict about the relationship between population size and genetic diversity?
options: Genetic diversity is independent of population size
Larger populations should harbor more genetic diversity because higher Ne increases the expected heterozygosity
Smaller populations always have higher heterozygosity
Mutation rate has no effect on heterozygosity
questions.explanation: The equation H = 4Neμ/(4Neμ + 1) shows that expected heterozygosity increases with both effective population size (Ne) and mutation rate (μ). As 4Neμ increases, H approaches 1.0. Large populations maintain more genetic diversity because drift (which removes variation) is weaker relative to mutation (which introduces variation). This prediction is broadly supported by comparative data: species with large population sizes (Drosophila, bacteria) generally have higher genetic diversity than species with small population sizes (large mammals, island endemics). Option A is incorrect because Ne directly appears in the equation and strongly influences H. Option C is incorrect because smaller Ne reduces H. Option D is incorrect because μ directly affects H — higher mutation rates increase diversity.

questions.question:
A researcher studying industrial melanism in peppered moths collected data from two time periods:

| Period | Light Environment | Dark (melanic) frequency | Light (typica) frequency | Predation rate on dark moths | Predation rate on light moths |
|--------|-----------------|------------------------|------------------------|-----------------------------|------------------------------|
| 1850 (pre-industrial) | Clean tree bark | 0.02 | 0.98 | High (conspicuous) | Low (camouflaged) |
| 1950 (industrial) | Soot-darkened bark | 0.95 | 0.05 | Low (camouflaged) | High (conspicuous) |

If anti-pollution legislation restored clean bark by 2000, what would population genetics predict for the melanic allele frequency?
options: The melanic frequency would remain at 0.95 because evolution is irreversible
The melanic allele would immediately go extinct in one generation
The melanic frequency would gradually decrease as directional selection now favors light moths on clean bark, potentially returning toward pre-industrial frequencies over many generations
The melanic frequency would increase further because darkened moths are always more fit
questions.explanation: If the environment shifts back to favoring light moths (clean bark makes melanic moths conspicuous to predators), directional selection would reverse, gradually reducing the frequency of the melanic allele. This prediction has been confirmed by observational data: following clean air legislation in Britain, the frequency of the melanic form (carbonaria) declined from >95% to <10% over several decades. The decline is gradual rather than instantaneous because it takes multiple generations for selection to change allele frequencies, especially when the melanic allele is dominant (heterozygotes are still dark and somewhat selected against on clean bark, slowing the decline). Option A is incorrect because evolution is not irreversible — the direction of selection can change with environmental conditions. Option B is incorrect because selection against a common allele requires multiple generations to reduce its frequency substantially. Option D is incorrect because fitness depends on the environment — melanic moths are disadvantaged on clean bark.

questions.question: In a diploid population with effective size Ne = 50, what is the probability that a new neutral mutation will eventually reach fixation?
options: 1.00 (100%) because all mutations eventually fix
questions.explanation: For a neutral mutation in a diploid population, the fixation probability equals its initial frequency, which for a new mutation is 1/(2Ne) = 1/(2×50) = 1/100 = 0.01 or 1%. This is because a new mutation exists as a single copy in 2Ne total gene copies. Since the mutation is neutral (no fitness advantage or disadvantage), its probability of drifting to fixation equals its current frequency. While 99% of new neutral mutations are lost by drift, the 1% that fix do so by chance alone. This result, derived by Kimura, is fundamental to the neutral theory of molecular evolution. Option A is incorrect because this would be the fixation probability if the allele started at 50% frequency. Option B is incorrect because 0.02 would be the probability for Ne = 25. Option D is incorrect because the vast majority of new neutral mutations are lost by drift.

questions.question: The concept of 'genetic load' refers to the reduction in mean fitness of a population relative to the maximum possible fitness. Which of the following does NOT contribute to genetic load?
options: Mutation load: the accumulation of deleterious alleles maintained by recurrent mutation
Segregation load: the production of homozygotes with lower fitness in systems with heterozygote advantage
Migration load: the introduction of locally maladapted alleles through gene flow
Stabilizing selection load: the maintenance of optimal mean fitness with no reduction from the maximum
questions.explanation: Genetic load is the proportional decrease in mean population fitness caused by the presence of non-optimal genotypes. Stabilizing selection acting on a population already at the optimal mean does not create a 'stabilizing selection load' in the way described — rather, stabilizing selection maintains the optimal phenotype and any load from it would come from the continuous generation of deviant phenotypes by mutation and recombination, which is already captured by mutation load. Option A correctly identifies mutation load — deleterious alleles maintained by recurrent mutation reduce mean fitness. Option B correctly identifies segregation load — under heterozygote advantage, the obligate production of less-fit homozygotes each generation reduces mean fitness below the heterozygote maximum. Option C correctly identifies migration load — gene flow from populations adapted to different environments introduces locally suboptimal alleles, reducing local mean fitness.

questions.question: A researcher wants to test whether a new mutation conferring herbicide resistance in a weed population carries a fitness cost in the absence of herbicide. Which experimental design would provide the MOST direct evidence?
options: Spraying the weed population with herbicide and counting survivors
Measuring the growth rate and seed production of resistant vs. susceptible genotypes grown together in competition experiments without herbicide, replicated across multiple environments
Sequencing the resistance gene to determine its molecular mechanism
Surveying natural weed populations to estimate the frequency of the resistance allele
questions.explanation: Competition experiments between resistant and susceptible genotypes in herbicide-free conditions provide the most direct test of fitness costs. If resistant plants produce fewer seeds, grow more slowly, or are competitively inferior to susceptible plants in the absence of herbicide, this demonstrates a fitness cost of resistance. Replication across environments controls for genotype-by-environment interactions. The competition design is more ecologically relevant than growing genotypes separately because fitness costs often manifest under resource limitation and competition. Option A tests resistance efficacy, not fitness cost. Option C reveals the molecular basis but cannot directly measure fitness consequences. Option D provides correlational data but cannot establish causation — low resistance allele frequency could reflect recent mutation origin rather than fitness cost.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the concept of 'soft selection' versus 'hard selection' in population genetics?
options: Soft selection occurs in aquatic organisms; hard selection occurs in terrestrial organisms

Under soft selection, the number of survivors from each local deme is fixed regardless of genotype composition, so selection occurs through competition within demes; under hard selection, survival depends on absolute genotype fitness, and demes with lower mean fitness contribute fewer individuals to the next generation
Hard selection only involves natural selection while soft selection only involves sexual selection
Soft and hard selection are identical concepts with different names
questions.explanation: The distinction between soft and hard selection, formulated by Wallace and Christiansen, has important implications for genetic load and population regulation. Under soft selection (density-dependent, frequency-dependent within demes), the total number of survivors is fixed — competition determines which genotypes survive, but population output is constant. Under hard selection (density-independent), absolute fitness determines survival, and demes with lower mean fitness contribute fewer total individuals. Soft selection reduces the genetic load felt by the population because total output is maintained regardless of genotype composition. Hard selection imposes a greater demographic cost because low-fitness populations decline. This distinction matters for understanding how many loci can be under selection simultaneously without driving populations to extinction (Haldane's cost of selection). Option A is unrelated to the actual definitions. Option C incorrectly limits each type to one form of selection. Option D is incorrect because the concepts are fundamentally different in their population-level consequences.

questions.question: A small population of deer was founded by 8 individuals on an island. After 50 generations, the population grew to 5,000 individuals. Compared to the mainland source population, which genetic pattern is MOST expected in the island population?
options: Higher genetic diversity due to rapid population growth
Identical allele frequencies to the mainland population
Increased genetic diversity due to higher mutation rates on the island
Reduced genetic diversity and potentially different allele frequencies due to the founder effect, with rare mainland alleles likely absent from the island population
questions.explanation: The founder effect — a form of genetic drift occurring when a new population is established by a small number of individuals — produces two major effects: (1) reduced genetic diversity because only a small sample of the mainland gene pool was captured in the 8 founders, and rare alleles were likely not included; (2) allele frequencies that may differ substantially from the mainland source due to random sampling. Even though the population subsequently grew to 5,000, the genetic diversity lost during the founding bottleneck cannot be recovered quickly (new mutations accumulate slowly). The island population will have lower allelic richness and potentially different allele frequencies than the mainland source. Option A is incorrect because population growth after the founding event does not restore lost alleles. Option B is unlikely because random sampling of only 8 individuals would not perfectly represent the mainland gene pool. Option C is incorrect because migration to an island does not increase mutation rates.

questions.question:
A study compared the rate of nonsynonymous substitutions (dN) to synonymous substitutions (dS) for different categories of genes in mammalian genomes:

| Gene Category | Mean dN/dS |
|--------------|------------|
| Histone genes | 0.005 |
| Housekeeping enzymes | 0.08 |
| Immune defense genes (MHC) | 1.45 |
| Pseudogenes | 0.98 |
| Reproductive proteins | 0.82 |

Which interpretation correctly links dN/dS ratios to the type of selection acting on each gene category?
options: All genes are evolving neutrally at the same rate
Histones show strong positive selection, while MHC genes show purifying selection

Genes with dN/dS < 1 are under purifying selection (functional constraint), genes with dN/dS ≈ 1 are evolving neutrally (pseudogenes), and genes with dN/dS > 1 show evidence of positive selection driving amino acid diversification (MHC, reproductive proteins)
Pseudogenes are under the strongest selection because their dN/dS ratio is closest to 1.0
questions.explanation: The dN/dS ratio is a powerful indicator of the type of selection acting on protein-coding genes. dN/dS < 1 indicates purifying selection: nonsynonymous (amino acid-changing) mutations are selectively removed because they disrupt protein function.
